data.text:
Alba Galocha as Queen Joanna of Castile in The Spanish Princess.

Joanna was given a significant education as a girl, and trained for a marriage that would extend the kingdoms power. In 1495, Joanna was showing signs of religious skepticism, and her mother, Queen Isabella, became alarmed. Because of this, Joanna was put under “La cuerda”, which is a punishment that involves being suspended by a rope with weights attached to your feet.

In 1496, at the age of sixteen, Joanna was married by proxy to the eighteen year old Phillip of Flanders. The two would go on to have six children, including two boys and four girls. In August, she left for Flanders, and would never see any of her siblings again (aside from Catherine of Aragon in 1506).

When Joanna’s brother, John, and her sister, Isabella, and both of their issues had died, Joanna became the heir to the spanish throne. And when Queen Isabella died in November of 1504, she became Queen of Castile, and her husband king.

Joanna was pregnant with her sixth child when her husband died on September 25th of 1506. With there now no king, Joanna attempted to rule in her own right as Queen of Castile, but the country fell in disorder, and her father, Ferdinand II, was restored as the king. However, Joanna refused to sign away her royal powers, and her father confined in the Royal Palace, where she is said to have gone “mad”. It has also been said that she took her husbands dead corpse with her, but this most definitely isn’t true. Her “madness” was most likely depression.

Ferdinand II died in 1516 with no male heir, so now Joanna was to succeed the throne once again. In October of 1517, her son, Charles, arrived in Asturias t o secure for him to rule as co-king. However, despite her agreement to this, she was not freed from her confinement.

With having his mother confined for the rest of her life, Charles throne would be ensured. This of course deteriorated Joanna’s mental health even further, and she supposedly became paranoid that some of the nuns that took care of her were trying to kill her. Charles even wrote to her caretakers, “It seems to me that the best and most suitable thing for you to do is to make sure that no person speaks with Her Majesty, for no good could come from it”.

Joanna passed away on April 12th of 1555 at the age of 75 in the Royal Palace at Tordesillas. She outlived all of her siblings, and is buried in the Royal Chapel of Granada in Spain, alongside her parents, Isabella I and Ferdinand II, and her husband, Phillip I.
